title.text: Can Character Embeddings Improve Cause-of-Death Classification for Verbal Autopsy Narratives?

abstractContent.text: We present two models for combining word and character embeddings for cause-of-death classification of verbal autopsy reports using the text of the narratives.

We find that for smaller datasets (500 to 1000 records), adding character information to the model improves classification, making character-based CNNs a promising method for automated verbal autopsy coding.

tableCaptions.text: Table 2: Results from 10-fold cross-validation for each  age group in the MDS dataset.

Table 3: Confusion matrices for the neonatal test set  (iteration 0). Top: results from the word embedding  model. Bottom: results from the embedding concate- nation model. Rows are the correct CoD categories and  columns are the predicted categories. n is the number  of records belonging to that category in the test set.
